review.title: Reasoning by Cases in Structured Argumentation
review.abstract: We extend the $ASPIC^+$ framework for structured argumentation so as to allow applications of the reasoning by cases inference scheme for defeasible arguments. Given an argument with conclusion `$A$ or $B$', an argument based on $A$ with conclusion $C$, and an argument based on $B$ with conclusion $C$, we allow the construction of an argument with conclusion $C$. We show how our framework leads to different results than other approaches in non-monotonic logic for dealing with disjunctive information, such as disjunctive default theory or approaches based on the OR-rule (which allows to derive a defeasible rule `If ($A$ or $B$) then $C$', given two defeasible rules `If $A$ then $C$' and `If $B$ then $C$'). We raise new questions regarding the subtleties of reasoning defeasibly with disjunctive information, and show that its formalization is more intricate than one would presume.

sections.heading: 3 Argumentation by cases
sections.text: In this section, we define structured reasoning frameworks (SAFs) for case-by-case reasoning; our starting point is an instantiation of the ASPIC + framework (with no priorities, no erroneous premises, and no overlaps); we adapt ASPIC + as follows. (i) We define a new type of argument called the rbc argument (see point 4 in Definition 4); using rbc arguments, we can argue by case in an argumentation formalism (Section 3.1); (ii) We generalize the attack relationship to include case-by-argument using the concept of a hypothetical argument (Section 3.2); and we define a logical consequence relationship for the resulting SAFs (Section 3.3). We briefly discuss the metatheoretical properties of our framework (Section 3.4).
